div.p: Titanium(IV) phosphates have received a considerable attention in the last decades by their properties as ion exchangers, sorbents and convenient matrices for chemical modification. In recent years, new types of titanium(IV) phosphate based materials have been synthesized by high temperature solid state reactions and by hydrothermal methods under mild conditions. The latter approach is of a special interest because it allows the synthesis of metastable phases that could exhibit ion exchange and catalytic properties.

A sample with the empirical formula, Ti&L&Ou, was obtained hydrothermally from titanium(IV) chloride in phosphoric acid solutions. The reaction mixture was sealed and heated at 190°C for 10 days. On the other hand three-dimensional compounds can be obtained by thermal treatment of ion-exchange phases of lamellar phosphates. Heating at 900°C r-Ti(C~.~H&'O&rH~O gives rise to the compound a-CsTi3P5019.

The crystal structure of Ti$L&O~~ was ab initio determined from synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction data. The X-ray data were collected on the beam line BM16. A finely ground sample of Ti&l&01r was loaded in a 1.0 mm borosillicate capillary and mounted in a rotatory goniometer. Room-temperature data were collected using an incident wavelength of

After careful optimization of the appropriate profile parameters and the intensities themselves, 947 p values were extracted from the raw data; The ti data were used as the starting data for the direct-methods program SHELXS-86'. A plausible solution was found assuming the space group Pi showing the positions of all non-hydrogen atoms. Using this model, a Rietveld refinement against the synchrotron powder X-ray data was carried out. Successful convergence was accomplished, RW= 13.3, x2 = 18.6. The H-atom positions were determined by Fourier Difference Synthesis, using constant-wavelength neutron powder diffraction data (h = 1 S94 A). The structure consists of a three-dimensional network of Ti0 6 octahedra and FQ tetrahedra linked by vertex sharing. The two independent titanium atoms are connected by an oxo bridge and two independent water molecules are linked to one type of Ti atoms. The topology of this structure consists of a Ti/P/O framework enclosing two principal channels running parallel to the a axis, into which the H atoms of the water molecules project, one different molecule by channel.
